expectations:
- MUST be in Latin American Spanish
      - Should break down each type of chemical bond into separate lessons
      - Should cover VSEPR, hybridization, and polarity as individual topics
      - Should not combine theoretical models in single lessons
      
      
  - Each lesson should cover a SINGLE, SPECIFIC concept that can be explained within 10 short tweets
  - Break down topics into the smallest, most manageable units possible, so that each lesson can be learned in 2-3 minutes
  - If a topic is too broad, split it into multiple lessons
  - Each lesson should be extremely focused on a SINGLE concept
  - If a lesson is too broad, split it into multiple lessons
  - If you find yourself using "AND", "OR", or "VS" in a title, you should split it into separate lessons
  - Lesson titles should be short and specific to the exact concept covered
  - Build a logical progression from basic to advanced concepts
  - Ensure lessons build on knowledge from previous lessons
  - Focus lessons for this specific chapter, not the entire course
  - Don't include summary or review lessons. For example, do NOT create a lesson title "Summary of Key Concepts" or "Review of Chapter"
  - Don't include assessment or quiz lessons
  - Don't include final project or capstone lessons
  - Should follow the language specified by language parameter
  - Should follow title and description guidelines: no fluff, be concise, straight to the point
  - Descriptions should be concise and straight to the point, no fluff/filler words (avoid "learn", "understand", "explore", "introduction to", etc.)
  - You don't need to evaluate the output format here, just focus on the lesson content quality
  - Include an extensive list of lessons to cover all the concepts needed to learn the chapter. Complex topics will usually requiere more than 100 lessons
  
  Things to check:
  - Is each lesson too broad? If so, it should be broken down further
  - Can each concept be explained in 10 short tweets or less? If not, it should be broken down
  - Does each lesson focus on a single specific concept? If not, it should be split
  - Does it have lessons that don't belong in this chapter? If so, they should be removed

rankings.reasoning: Model B provides the most comprehensive coverage with 122 lessons organized with excellent logical progression. Topics are well-segmented: structures of Lewis broken into multiple lessons (conteo de electrones, esqueleto molecular, pares enlazantes, pares libres, cargas formales), all bond types separated, VSEPR thoroughly covered with both electronic and molecular geometries, hibridación split by type with associated geometries, TOM with detailed concepts like mezcla s-p and HOMO/LUMO. Descriptions are concise and specific. Follows Latin American Spanish. Includes advanced topics like ciclo de Born-Haber, regla de Bent. Minor issues: some lessons could be further split (e.g., 'Relación de TOM con bandas' is somewhat broad).

Model I offers 92 lessons with excellent granularity and logical organization. Topics are properly separated: Lewis writing broken into 6 sequential steps, VSEPR geometries thoroughly covered including derived geometries (AX notation used consistently), hibridación separated by type with geometry correlations, TEV and TOM properly distinguished. Good coverage of polarity as individual topic with 7 focused lessons. Latin American Spanish is correct. Descriptions are concise and accurate. Some lessons like 'Comparación de enlaces iónico, covalente y metálico' could be split further.

Model E provides 100 lessons with good coverage and proper separation of concepts. Strong points: exceptions to octet rule split into 3 lessons, Lewis structures with charge formal calculations, VSEPR with geometric distortions well covered, hibridación types properly separated, MO theory includes HOMO/LUMO. Good focus on individual concepts. Latin American Spanish correct. Some lessons like 'Enlace doble como σ + π' combine concepts that could be separate. Polarity section is well developed with 5 focused lessons.

Model A offers 73 lessons with proper separation of bond types, VSEPR geometries, and hibridación types. Good coverage of MO theory including paramagnetic/diamagnetic molecules. Resonance and formal charge are separate lessons. Latin American Spanish is correct. Descriptions are clear and concise. However, some topics could be further broken down (e.g., 'Estructuras de Lewis' is too broad as a single lesson). Missing some derived geometries and less coverage of polarity concepts compared to higher-ranked models.

Model J provides 95 lessons with good organization. Bond types separated, VSEPR covered with both electronic and molecular geometries, hibridación types well split, MO theory includes sigma/pi orbitales moleculares. Good coverage of resonance as separate topic. Latin American Spanish correct. However, some lessons still combine concepts (e.g., 'Propiedades de los compuestos iónicos' could be split). Less detailed coverage of Lewis structure construction steps compared to Models B and I.

Model D provides 60 lessons covering main concepts adequately. Bond types are separated, VSEPR geometries covered, hibridación types listed individually. Latin American Spanish correct. However, lacks the granularity expected - for example, Lewis structures construction not broken into steps, MO theory coverage is basic (missing HOMO/LUMO, detailed diagrams). 'Propiedades de compuestos iónicos' is too broad. Missing some derived VSEPR geometries. Polarity section limited.

Model C offers 82 lessons with reasonable coverage. Good separation of bond types, VSEPR geometries well covered, hibridación types separated. Includes useful concepts like HOMO/LUMO. Latin American Spanish correct. However, some lessons are too condensed (e.g., 'Enlace iónico' as first lesson is too broad without separate definition lesson). Lewis structure construction not sufficiently broken down. Missing some detailed steps in processes. Some descriptions could be more precise.

Model H provides only 41 lessons, which is significantly below the expected 100+ for complex chemistry topics. While concepts are correctly in Latin American Spanish and topics are properly focused, coverage is insufficient. Missing many derived VSEPR geometries, Lewis structure construction steps, many MO theory details. Bond types covered but not with sufficient depth. Hibridación types present but missing associated geometry lessons. Polarity section too brief.

Model G offers only 38 lessons, far below expected coverage. Topics are overly condensed - 'Compartición electrónica' combines multiple concepts, MO theory only has 5 lessons. Missing many VSEPR derived geometries, Lewis structure detailed steps, polarity analysis specifics. Latin American Spanish is correct. Descriptions are concise but coverage is inadequate for a chapter on chemical bonding. Hibridación types are listed but without geometry detail lessons.

Model K provides 65 lessons but has organizational issues. Many lessons have redundant titles (e.g., 'Geometría lineal electrónica' and 'Geometría molecular lineal' repeated patterns). Some content errors (e.g., 'Geometría molecular piramidal pentagonal' for AX₅E is incorrect - should be square pyramidal for octahedral with one lone pair). Missing Lewis structure construction steps. Limited polarity coverage. Latin American Spanish correct but less thorough coverage.

Model F provides only 56 lessons with several issues. Many lessons are too brief or combine concepts inappropriately (e.g., 'Ejemplos de enlaces iónicos' and 'Ejemplos de enlace covalentes' violate guidelines about examples as separate lessons). Some descriptions are vague (e.g., 'Ejemplos como NH3 y H2O en VSEPR'). Missing detailed Lewis structure construction, many VSEPR derived geometries, MO theory depth. Polarity section insufficient. Coverage significantly below expected 100+ lessons.

Model B is the superior output. It provides the most extensive list (105 lessons) and adheres most strictly to the granularity guidelines. It breaks down complex topics into very specific, manageable lessons (e.g., splitting 'Lewis Structures' into counting, skeleton, pairing, etc., and splitting 'Overlap' into s-s, s-p, etc.). It includes advanced but relevant topics like the Born-Haber cycle, Bent's rule, and Band theory, ensuring a comprehensive chapter coverage. The language is correct, and it avoids 'AND/OR/VS' in titles effectively.

Model E is excellent, with a high lesson count (88) and great granularity. It effectively breaks down properties (e.g., splitting Maleability and Ductility) and VSEPR repulsions into separate lessons. The content covers all required areas including MO theory and hybridization details. It follows the negative constraints regarding title phrasing well.

Model A provides a very solid list (72 lessons) that covers all key topics including detailed VSEPR geometries and MO theory. It adheres strictly to the title formatting rules (no 'AND/VS'). It is ranked below B and E because it tends to lump properties into single lessons (e.g., 'Propiedades de los compuestos iónicos') rather than splitting them, which makes those specific lessons less focused than the top two models.

Model J offers a high quantity of lessons (85) and good content coverage. However, it is ranked lower than A because it violates the title constraints in several places (e.g., 'Orden de enlace y estabilidad', 'Relación entre orden, longitud y energía...'). It also lumps properties into single lessons similar to Model A.

Model I has a good lesson count (82) and detailed content, particularly on VSEPR derived shapes. However, it explicitly violates the negative constraint regarding title phrasing multiple times (e.g., 'Geometría electrónica vs geometría molecular', 'Átomo, ion y molécula'). This formatting oversight lowers its score despite the good content.

Model K follows the formatting rules well but is less comprehensive (65 lessons) than the higher-ranked models. The lesson titles are somewhat repetitive, and the breakdown of concepts is adequate but not as detailed as models B or E.

Model C covers the basics (72 lessons) but violates the 'VS' rule in titles ('Geometría electrónica vs geometría molecular'). The progression is acceptable, but the content depth is standard and lacks the granular detail of the top models.

Model D has a lower lesson count (57) and uses 'AND' in titles (e.g., 'Maleabilidad y ductilidad'), failing to split broader concepts. It covers the basics but lacks the 'extensive' nature requested for complex topics.
Model F is too brief (53 lessons) and relies on 'vs.' in titles, violating constraints. The content is very basic and does not explore the complexity of the chapter sufficiently.
Model H is significantly lacking in quantity (39 lessons) and depth. It fails to meet the requirement for an extensive list covering complex topics.
Model G is the weakest output with only 37 lessons. It misses many specific geometries and details required for a complete chapter on chemical bonds.

Es el más cercano a la granularidad exigida: divide Lewis en pasos (conteo, esqueleto, pares, cargas), separa VSEPR en subideas (grupos electrónicos, preferencia ecuatorial, efecto de enlaces múltiples), y trata hibridación con lecciones separadas incluso para geometría asociada. Cubre iónico/covalente/metálico con bastante detalle (Born–Haber, coordinación, radios, aleaciones, estructuras metálicas) y polaridad con piezas breves. Debilidades: no llega ni cerca de >100 lecciones y ocasionalmente mezcla en un título/idea (p. ej., algunos títulos de relaciones “orden–energía/orden–longitud” y “Paramagnetismo desde MO” une dos conceptos).

Muy completo y con progresión lógica; descompone Lewis y VSEPR en pasos claros y añade derivados AXnEm. Incluye TEV, TOM, hibridación y polaridad con un nivel de detalle alto para “capítulo”. Problemas: incumple reglas explícitas del usuario al incluir una lección de “Comparación de enlaces iónico, covalente y metálico” (título tipo “y”), y varias lecciones combinan modelos/ideas (p. ej., “Paramagnetismo y diamagnetismo en TOM”, “Polaridad molecular y geometría”). Aun así, la cobertura es sólida y mayor que la mayoría.

Buena cobertura de enlace iónico/covalente/metálico, VSEPR (con varias geometrías derivadas), TEV, hibridación, TOM y polaridad; los títulos suelen ser específicos. Debilidades notables: varias secciones son demasiado “macro” para 10 tuits (p. ej., “Diagrama de orbitales moleculares” sin acotar, “Orbitales moleculares en moléculas homonucleares/heteronucleares” puede ser amplio). También mezcla teorías dentro del capítulo sin cuidar la restricción “no combinar modelos teóricos en una lección” en algunos puntos (p. ej., conexiones sigma/pi con enlaces simples/dobles/triples). Lista no es “extensa” según la expectativa (>100).

Estructura bastante ordenada y granular en Lewis (incluye cálculo y criterios separados), VSEPR (dominio, número estérico, repulsiones separadas) y enlaces iónico/covalente/metálico. Buen cumplimiento de “un concepto por lección” en general. Fallas: varias lecciones siguen siendo compuestas o ambiguas (p. ej., “Forma angular” mezcla casos de 3 y 4 dominios; “Isomería geométrica…” no encaja bien y su título sugiere tema mayor). También está lejos de 100+ lecciones.

Cubre lo esencial del capítulo (Lewis, octeto y excepciones, tipos de enlace, VSEPR con varias formas, TEV, hibridación, TOM, magnetismo). Bastante claro y en español. Debilidades: menor granularidad (Lewis no está por pasos; VSEPR sin detalles como preferencia ecuatorial; polaridad apenas). Varias lecciones son más amplias de lo ideal para “10 tuits”. No es lista extensa.

Cobertura amplia (incluye polaridad con vectores, VSEPR con geometría electrónica y molecular, hibridación con casos en dobles/triples, TOM con ejemplos H2/O2/N2, resonancia). Sin embargo, mezcla conceptos con frecuencia en títulos tipo “Relación entre orden, longitud y energía de enlace” y “Diferencias entre enlaces sigma y pi” (usa “y”), y hay redundancias (longitud/energía/orden aparecen dos veces). También algunas lecciones son demasiado grandes (p. ej., “Diferencia de electronegatividad” como clasificador completo).

Lista relativamente limpia y conceptos básicos presentes (enlaces, Lewis, VSEPR, hibridación, sigma/pi, MO, polaridad). Pero es poco granular, omite muchos subcasos (derivadas VSEPR, pasos Lewis, etc.) y no cumple la expectativa de lista extensa. También agrupa ideas en varias descripciones (p. ej., electronegatividad como criterio general; polaridad molecular considerando geometría y dipolos).

Cobertura razonable de enlaces y VSEPR/hibridación/MO/polaridad, con algunos temas extra (Pauling, tendencias periódicas). Problemas: no está en español latino consistente (usa comillas/anglicismo “seesaw”), y mete temas que se sienten fuera o demasiado amplios para el “capítulo” (bandas, maleabilidad+ductilidad juntas). Granularidad irregular: algunas lecciones son procedimientos completos o mezclan dos ideas. No es extensa.

Muy básico: cubre tipos de enlace, VSEPR, hibridación, MO y polaridad pero con poca descomposición (Lewis prácticamente no aparece; VSEPR casi sólo lista geometrías). Incluye varias lecciones de “Ejemplos” y propiedades agrupadas, lo que reduce enfoque de un solo concepto. Incumple la expectativa de profundidad y lista extensa.

Demasiado corto y poco granular; omite Lewis (clave del capítulo) y polaridad está muy resumida. Además agrupa conceptos en una sola lección (p. ej., “Longitud y energía de enlace covalente”). Falta progresión detallada y está muy lejos del volumen requerido.

Tiene varios errores/ruido conceptual y de encaje: títulos/descr. confusos en metales (“Propiedades de conductividad…” hablando de maleabilidad), VSEPR incluye geometrías improbables/incorrectas para este nivel (“piramidal pentagonal: AX5E” no es estándar en el esquema básico), y varias etiquetas AX/pares no cuadran. También carece de Lewis por pasos y mezcla/duplica temas. Aunque es más largo que algunos, la calidad y corrección lo penalizan.
